message: “Those people now are going to migrate to some other website or mobile app or use some other means to continue that behavior, so it’s up to law enforcement to identify those,” said Jon Meyer, a special agent for the state Department of Justice’s Division of Criminal Investigation field office in Eau Claire.  “There is not just one tool or methodology that is going to work to proactively identify people engaged in child exploitation.”

data.description: The disturbing headlines just keep popping up. “Man caught in online child sex sting.” “Man sentenced for seeking sex with two girls.” “Prison for man caught in child sex sting.” Those are just a few of the Leader-Telegram headlines so far this year for cases involving what local police ...
data.title: When child sex trafficking migrated to the web, police went on the offense
